race.name: Monaco Gravel Race
race.tagline: Monaco/French Alpsâ€”110km of steep climbs, 2,500m elevation, iconic location, 20-25% DNF.

terrain.surface: 70% gravel, 30% paved roads. Monaco/French Alpsâ€”steep climbs, technical. 2,500 m over 110 km = very steep. Monaco start/finish. Technical rating: 5/5.

biased_opinion.summary: Monaco Gravel Race is Monaco/French Alpsâ€”110 km, 2,500 m elevation. Founded ~2020. 70% gravel, 30% paved. Steep climbs, technical. 300-500 riders. Monaco start/finish (iconic location). October autumn conditions (12-22Â°C). Expensive entry (â‚¬150-â‚¬200 / $165-$220). If you want Monaco/French Alps iconic location with brutal steep climbs, this is it. If you need manageable elevation or budget race, skip it. 20-25% DNF.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: Monaco Gravel Race is Monaco/French Alps brutality. 110 km, 2,500 m, very steep, 20-25% DNF. If you want Monaco iconic location with French Alps climbs, this is it. If you need manageable elevation or budget race, skip it. Expensive but iconic. Brutal.

logistics.travel_summary: Fly to Nice (NCE). Rental car or shuttle (30 km, 30-minute drive to Monaco). Monaco lodgingâ€”expensive, book early. Day-before packet pickup. Race October. Post-race party in Monaco.
logistics.food_options: Aid stations on course. Post-race party in Monaco.

course_description.character: 110 km, 2,500 m. 70% gravel, 30% paved. Monaco/French Alpsâ€”steep climbs, technical. Technical rating: 5/5.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: French Alps Steep Climbs
suffering_zones.description: 2,500 m over 110 km = very steep. French Alps climbs. Brutal.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: Very low gears. Pace conservatively. 2,500 m / 110 km is brutal. 20-25% DNF here.

suffering_zones.name: Throughout: Technical Terrain
suffering_zones.description: Technical French Alps gravel. Steep climbs. Technical rating: 5/5.
suffering_zones.survival_strategy: 35-40mm tubeless. Technical skills required. Steep climbs. Focus on next aid.

course_description.signature_challenge: 110 km + 2,500 m elevation = very steep. Monaco/French Alps. 20-25% DNF.

history.origin_story: Monaco Gravel Race founded ~2020. Monaco start/finish. 110 km, 300-500 riders. Monaco/French Alps. Steep climbs.
history.reputation: Monaco gravel scene. Monaco/French Alps. Iconic location. Steep climbs. Brutal. 20-25% DNF.

logistics.explanation: Jan StÃ¶ckli's travel report reveals the challenge: planned Friday departure delayed by Simplon Pass closure, forcing a 4:30 AM Saturday start to reach Monaco by midday. Once there, race execution proved solid with organized communication via info@monacogravelrace.fr and clear UCI World Series protocols.

length.explanation: Jan StÃ¶ckli stayed with the lead group early but "after about a lap and a half, the effort caught up with me. I started to fade and couldn't maintain the early pace." The race becomes extremely demanding after ~60km, suggesting 68 miles hits the sweet spot between substantial and manageable. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: StÃ¶ckli describes "the relentless vibrations and shocks during the climbs were tough on the muscles" through terrain featuring the Col de Braus gravel tracks and technical descents on both asphalt and gravel. The course demands serious bike handling skills through Mercantour's varied mountain terrain. Among the most technical in gravel, on par with Badlands.

elevation.explanation: "The course was brutal â€” 120 kilometers with 2,600 meters of climbing. A true mountain test," reports Jan StÃ¶ckli. Starting from Peille Village at 650 meters, the route tackles Col de Braus and Col des Boeufs with relentless vertical punishment that defines the race character. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 70Â°F and lows of 58Â°F, with a 37% chance of rain on any given day. April racing in the Mercantour region between Mediterranean coast and mountains creates variable spring conditions. No specific weather incidents reported from the 2025 inaugural edition, suggesting manageable but potentially unpredictable conditions depending on elevation and exposure. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Starting from Peille Village at 650 meters with climbs reaching Col de Braus elevation means minimal altitude physiological effects. The significant elevation gain occurs in foothills rather than high-altitude terrain where oxygen becomes a limiting factor. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds â€” no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The route connects medieval Peille Village through Mercantour National Park to Saint AgnÃ¨s, described as "the highest hilltop village on the Mediterranean coast." Riders traverse the Farghet Plateau and Guadiana River sections, experiencing protected alpine wilderness few will see outside this event.

prestige.explanation: Mads Wurtz Schmidt calls his Monaco victory "incredibly meaningful" as his "second UCI Gravel World Series win this season." UCI World Series qualifier status among only 45 global races, combined with the Monaco location, places this in gravel racing's top tier.

race_quality.explanation: Schmidt describes the "Monaco Gravel course as not only beautiful but also incredibly challenging." The course threading through Mercantour National Park with technical Col de Braus gravel sections and varied descents delivers premium racing terrain that tests elite riders.

experience.explanation: Morgan Aguirre found the experience "unforgettable" with "support from the crowd and my team." Racing from medieval Peille through protected Mercantour wilderness to coastal hilltop villages creates an adventure that transcends typical gravel events.

community.explanation: UCI World Series events attract serious international fields, bringing together riders who've committed to chasing World Championship qualification. The logistics of reaching Monaco filter out casual participants, leaving a focused group of committed gravel racers. Limited research shows the community aspect, but the barrier to entry suggests quality over quantity.

field_depth.explanation: Elite winners Schmidt and Aguirre dominated with significant time gaps - Aguirre won by 5 minutes, Schmidt by 3:43. StÃ¶ckli noted "the field was amazingly strong on the ascents," but the 500-rider field size remains modest for a UCI World Series event. Similar competitive depth to Rule of Three.

value.explanation: Racing in Monaco means paying Monaco prices for everything from accommodation to meals. The course delivers premium terrain through Mercantour National Park, but you're paying a luxury destination premium for 68 miles of gravel. Registration fees aren't published, but nothing about this location suggests budget-friendly.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs â‚¬150-â‚¬200. StÃ¶ckli's travel complications requiring overnight stops and early morning departures highlight the logistical costs of reaching Monaco. Racing in one of the world's most expensive destinations means accommodation, dining, and transportation costs hit hard during race weekend. Higher total cost than Badlands.

final_verdict.one_liner: A UCI qualifier that trades the usual gravel brutality for Alpine scenery and climbing legs that'll make you question your gear choices.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you can handle 121 feet of climbing per mile on short, punchy ascents, this is your European gravel vacation with World Championship qualification upside. The Mercantour park setting means you're climbing through postcard scenery instead of Kansas cornfields. Skip it if you prefer sustained efforts over constant gear changes, or if you think 68 miles sounds easy because the math doesn't lie on those repeated kicks.
final_verdict.alternatives: Dirty Kanza offers similar UCI points without the airline ticket, while Gravel Worlds qualifiers like SBT GRVL give you high desert instead of Alpine views. If you want European gravel without the Monaco price tag, consider Gravel One Fifty in the UK for comparable terrain and fewer tourist crowds.

videos.description:
In this second episode of the Gravel Diary, we head to Montecarlo, where Jan StÃ¶ckli and Simon Pellaud took on their first UCI gravel race together: the Monaco Gravel Race UCI 2025.

Our Gravellers captured the full experience in video - from their homes in Switzerland to the rugged, sun-soaked trails of Monaco, their journey is packed with grit, speed, and heart-pounding action. Experience every bump, turn, and breakthrough as they dive headfirst into their debut on the UCI Gravel Series series.

videos.title: THE FILM [4K] - Monaco di Baviera Classic 2025. The ultimate unsupported ultracycling challenge.
videos.description:
Step into the world of ultracycling with The FILM â€“ Monaco di Baviera Classic 2025, the official movie of the ultimate unsupported ultracycling challenge.

Follow the riders as they push their limits across stunning landscapes, facing solitude, fatigue, and the raw beauty of the open road. This is not just a challenge â€” it's a journey of resilience, joy, and pure passion for ultracycling.

Supported by:
Specialized Munich
MNSTRY Sports Nutrition @MNSTRY1800 

Discover more at: https://ultracyclingchallenges.com

quotes.text: It's been pissing rain all night. It's going to be wet, muddy, and stony. 120ks of racing. Minus 5 because they put the finish line in the middle of the forest.

The podium was secured until 7ks to go. The last case of downhill when I had a bad flat tire, we had like more than two minute advantage on the force. So I could put two of these small plug in my tire seal. Bump it up. Start again.

The bike is super fast. The wheels are really good. Like I had the 45 in front and 40 behind. It's on gravel. It's really really fast.
